subject: RE: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... OK, I see. ... Yes, of course. Most often that knowledge can be explained by using code, though. ... Perhaps precise, tight code isn t exactly the same
messageBody:
Jim Dixon wrote:
> On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:
>
>>> Telling people that code should not be commented, that comments are
>>> waste, remains extremely bad advice.
>>
>> This is true if you were only saying that.
>
> But that is precisely what I said. The bad advice was the
> _categorical_ statement that comments are waste.

OK, I see.

> On the other hand, if the code embodies application-specific
> knowledge, it is usually important and often essential to explain.

Yes, of course. Most often that knowledge can be explained by using
code, though.

> Walter was well known for his incredibly precise, tight code. It was
> beautiful.
>
> He was also very economical with comments. That wasn't so
> wonderful for those who had to decrypt the code when he wasn't there.

Perhaps "precise, tight" code isn't exactly the same as "expressive,
maintainable" code? I'd really like to see some code snippets the
maintaines had problems with...


>> Saying "write your code in a way that it doesn't need comments" is
>> very good advice, on the other hand.
>
> That I would agree with. Although some of us do like Javadocs.

I have never seen a javadoc comment I would have preferred over code. If
you can't have the code, Javadoc is very nice, though.

>> And in my experience you *can* learn
>> to write code in a way that you very seldom need to fall back on this
>> crutch.
>
> Crutch? Name-calling helps no one.

Sorry, I didn't mean it that way. A crutch is an important tool to me.
There are situations where I definitely want to have one. Most often I
want to avoid to need one, though. Exactly the same with comments.

> Can we return to JUnit and the thrill of unit testing?

I don't mind.

Take care, Ilja
